subject: A method for estimating number of junit test cases using Cyclomatic complexity
msgSnippet: Hi, I am trying to estimate effort for writing a regression test suite based on Junit for an existing system. The method used for estimation is very simple
messageBody:
Hi,
I am trying to estimate effort for writing a regression test suite based
on Junit for an existing system.
The method used for estimation is very simple (and possibly very wrong
too) as described below. I greatly appreciate all inputs and thoughts on
this. I googled and found no past or present precedent to estimating
Junit test efforts based on Code complexity measures. I may have missed
something important due to my ignorance and relative newness to Junit
and estimation. I shall gladly stand corrected by more knowledgeable
folks.

---------------------------------------------
*Hypotheses
The working hypothesis for the effort estimation was "a strong
corelation between cyclomatic complexity of existing code and the effort
to write junit tests for the code".

As a consequence of this hypothesis it is further purported that "the
number of independent execution paths (Cyclomatic complexity) is equal
to the number of test methods". This dictates some nasty terms to how
the junit tests must be structured but it is believed to be a *resonable
thing* for estimation purposes.


*The estimation method
Weighted Methods Per Class (WMPC) was used as a measure of complexity.
WMPC is defined to be "the sum of the complexity of all methods for a
class, where each method is weighted by its cyclomatic complexity. The
number of methods and the complexity of the methods involved is a
predictor of how much time and effort is required to develop and
maintain the class. Only methods specified in a class are included, that
is, any methods inherited from a parent are excluded."

The WMPC measured from the existing codebase was normalized for trivial
methods like getter and setters.

The effort was estimated using a simple formula:
Total Effort = Total number of test methods * Average effort for one
test method

The Total number of test methods is calculated as follows:-
Total test methods = Average WMPC of all classes * Number of classes

The Average effort for one test method (note that this is test method
and not test case class) was estimated from actual efforts.

*Sample calculation
Number of Classes = 973
Average WMPC ~= 9 (normalized for getter and setter methods. I used
Together ControlCenter->Metrics for all these measures)
Average effort per test method = 2 hours (It is upto the developer to
distribute the test methods in a test case classes)

Total effort for writing Junit tests = (9 * 973) * 2 hrs = 17, 514 hours
= 2189 Person Days.
(*huh..hmm*. Let the beatings begin. I can't adequaltely express in
words my manager's bewildered expression on seeing this number. But,
that's another story.)
---------------------------------------------

If the general direction of the estimation is correct I would want to
spend some time on refining the method to include all those important
factors I am sure I have missed out above. Suggestions and pointers
towards places I should look more closely to get a better grip is more
than welcome. Thank you your time and valuable feedback.


Regards,
Selva.
